content.formatted_body:

i meant May 6 9:00 - 10:00 PT, 1 hour later
No worries; I can make that too. Thanks for arranging!

content.body: `Array(Math.pow(2, 32) - 1).concat(1)` throws a RangeError about "too large" in node; in Safari it throws an OOM RangeError; in FF it seems to just hang. the spec seems to say it should throw a TypeError (https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-array.prototype.concat step 5.b.iii). am i reading it right? if so i can make a test262 test for it.
content.formatted_body: Array(Math.pow(2, 32) - 1).concat(1) throws a RangeError about "too large" in node; in Safari it throws an OOM RangeError; in FF it seems to just hang. the spec seems to say it should throw a TypeError (https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-array.prototype.concat step 5.b.iii). am i reading it right? if so i can make a test262 test for it.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: `Array(Math.pow(2, 32) - 1).concat(1)` throws a RangeError about "too large" in node; in Safari it throws an OOM RangeError; in FF it seems to just hang. the spec seems to say it should throw a TypeError (https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-array.prototype.concat step 5.b.iii). am i reading it right? if so i can make a test262 test for it.

Array(Math.pow(2, 32) - 1).concat(1) throws a RangeError about "too large" in node; in Safari it throws an OOM RangeError; in FF it seems to just hang. the spec seems to say it should throw a TypeError (https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-array.prototype.concat step 5.b.iii). am i reading it right? if so i can make a test262 test for it.

content.body: OOMs are implementation-defined and can really happen anywhere. the spec says a `TypeError` should be thrown for lengths that exceed that length, even without an implementation-defined OOM error
content.formatted_body: OOMs are implementation-defined and can really happen anywhere. the spec says a TypeError should be thrown for lengths that exceed that length, even without an implementation-defined OOM error

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: OOMs are implementation-defined and can really happen anywhere. the spec says a `TypeError` should be thrown for lengths that exceed that length, even without an implementation-defined OOM error
OOMs are implementation-defined and can really happen anywhere. the spec says a TypeError should be thrown for lengths that exceed that length, even without an implementation-defined OOM error

content.body: so Safari is certainly allowed to throw an OOM
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: so Safari is certainly allowed to throw an OOM

content.body: as for FF hanging, that's fine too, i think, from a compliance perspective
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: as for FF hanging, that's fine too, i think, from a compliance perspective

content.body: it might be undesirable to hang, but i don't think that's breaking compliance with the spec
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: it might be undesirable to hang, but i don't think that's breaking compliance with the spec
